I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested support from the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) to strengthen elderly care services in Yichang, Hubei Province. 
A fact-finding mission took place in Yichang in February–March 2014, and ADB reached an 
agreement with the Yichang Municipal Government (YMG) on the impact, outcome, outputs, 
costs and financing, implementation arrangements, and outline terms of reference for consulting 
services for the technical assistance (TA). The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 
1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The main demographic challenges facing the PRC in this century are the dramatic aging 
of its population and the scale of internal migration, which is largely driven by urbanization. The 
proportion of people above the age of 60 across the PRC is expected to grow from roughly 12% 
in 2010 to 34% by 2050.2 The PRC’s population is aging rapidly at a time when the per capita 
income remains modest; social security systems cover a broad portion of the population, but are 
still  insufficient to  meet  the financial  needs  of  retired  senior  citizens,  as  illustrated  by  the 
Yichang experience.3 The high cost of care for the elderly will require long-term care financial 
coverage mechanisms to avoid major inequities in the way people experience their life as 
seniors. Furthermore, the current acute shortage of caregivers and nurses specialized in elderly 
care, most of whom are women, is exacerbated by low compensation levels and working 
conditions that make these professions unattractive.4  
 
3.  The PRC has been addressing the consequences of its aging population since the late 
1970s, with successive policies to finance old age care, stimulate private sector participation, 
define the responsibilities of families, and organize community-wide responses to support the 
elderly. The PRC’s Twelfth Five-Year Plan, 2010–2015 further recognized these challenges. It 
called for establishing an old age care system (with targets for home-based care, community 
care,  and  institutional  care) 5  expanding  grassroots  aging  associations;  encouraging 
volunteerism among senior citizens; and improving health management services.  
 
4.  The 2012 revision of the Elderly Law includes requirements for local governments to 
develop  community  services  for  senior  citizens.6 The recent  opinions  of the  State  Council 
(September 2013) to accelerate the development of the elderly care service industry recognizes 
the  progress  made  and  the  significant  challenges  that  remain.7 The  challenges  include

http://www.un.org/en/development/desa/publications/world-population-prospects-the-2010-revision.html   
3  The average monthly pension for a former state employee is CNY2,300, for an employee of a firm CNY1,400, and 
for rural citizens CNY60 (shared by the Bureau of Human Resources and Social Security of Yichang Municipality to

4  By 2015, 15 million older people in the PRC will require daily care, while currently there are only 300,000 people

Presentation at the Asia/Pacific Regional Conference on Ageing 2012: Rapid ageing:  a caring future. Myanmar. 8–
11 May). 
5  Current targets are 90% of elderly to age at home supported by home care services, 7% to receive community-
based services, and 3% institutional services. (National People's Congress. 2011. Twelfth Five-Year Plan for 
National Economic and Social Development, 2011–2015. Beijing.) 
6  Law of the People's Republic of China on Protection of the Rights and Interests of the Elderly. 
7  State Council. 2013. Opinions on Promoting the Development of Senior Care Service Industry (Circular No. 35). 
Beijing.

2   
insufficient elderly care services and products, an underdeveloped market, and imbalanced 
regional rural–urban development. The opinions of the State Council include a comprehensive 
list  of  policy  directions;  set  development  goals;  describe  organization  and  management 
arrangements; and assign responsibilities to combine public, private, and civil society efforts.  
 
5.  In the PRC, children traditionally took primary responsibility for caring for their parents’ 
medical and nonmedical needs (e.g., daily activities and emotional and financial requirements). 
However, the ability of children to meet this traditional responsibility is increasingly challenged 
by several factors, including small family size (resulting in part from the one child policy), high 
labor force mobility, the high labor participation rate of women, increasing financial burdens on 
the families of children with the duty to care, and the eroding importance of filial piety. Support 
provided by the government for the poor elderly includes (i) payment of social pensions for poor 
rural  and  urban  citizens;  (ii)  provision  of  residential  or  community-based  care services for 
selected elderly living on social assistance; and (iii) support to the most destitute, including 
childless old people and elderly whose children also live in poverty. 8 
 
6.  Currently, only childless elderly people living on social assistance such as the “Three 
Nos” in the cities and “Five Guarantees” households in the countryside are provided residential 
or  community-based  care  services  by  the  government.9 Other  elderly  welfare  assistance 
recipients are generally ineligible for care subsidies by the government. There is a need for the 
government to expand subsidies for these elderly people, including to low-income households 
that are slightly above the poverty threshold (the marginal poor).10  
 
7.  Yichang  Municipality  submitted  a  project  proposal  to  ADB  through  the  Ministry  of 
Finance to provide TA to strengthen local policies and strategies, and to update its elderly 
service facilities construction plan as a way for the municipality to address elderly care issues 
for  the  urban  population.11 The municipality  previously  adopted  an  elderly  service facilities 
construction plan in urban areas of Yichang City in accordance with the PRC’s Twelfth Five-
Year Plan. Hubei Province has selected Yichang to become a model city for the provision of 
elderly care in the PRC. The TA findings will potentially be replicable in Hubei and nationally, 
and will contribute to the growing body of knowledge on planning elderly care services in the 
PRC.  
 
                                                
8  The latter benefits are delivered through two major means-tested social assistance schemes: (i) wubao (Five 
Guarantees Program), which subsidizes the rural elderly who lack family caregivers, working ability, and income; 
and (ii) dibao (minimum living standard guarantee scheme), which provides cash assistance for urban and rural 
households with per capita incomes less than the locally determined poverty threshold. While a social pension has 
been widely adopted across the country, its scope is limited. Government subsidies for senior citizens aged 80 and 
above consist of monthly payments of CNY50–CNY300 per person. 
9  “Three Nos” and “Five Guarantees” elderly households refer to elderly who have no family caregivers, working 
ability, and income. 
10 Marginal poor households are usually defined as those with household incomes 150%–170% higher than the local 
dibao threshold. 
11 In 2012, Yichang Municipality had a total population of over 4.00 million, and an urban population of 1.34 million; 
there were 652,100 senior citizens over 60 years of age, representing about 16.06% of the overall population, and 
above the national average of 13.70%.

3 
III.  THE POLICY AND ADVISORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of the TA will be a more inclusive and affordable elderly care system in 
Yichang. The outcome will be a balanced elderly services strategic development plan (covering 
infrastructure, community, and home-based care) for Yichang.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  To prepare an elderly services strategic development plan for Yichang, the TA will (i) 
identify national and international best practices on elderly care and analyze their applicability to 
Yichang Municipality, (ii) provide capacity development support to key stakeholders in Yichang 
to increase their understanding of elderly needs assessment and services planning, and (iii) 
implement  a  participatory  planning  process  to  develop  a  strategic  elderly  care  services 
development  plan  covering  institutional,  community,  and  home-based  services  (including 
opportunities to initiate public–private partnerships).  
 
10.  Key activities of the TA will be organized under four outputs: 
(i)  Output 1: Study report on  the national and international experience on 
elderly care. The TA will review national and international literature on elderly 
care and service planning, identify best practices, and prepare a study report. 
Anticipated topics of interest are the role of public, private, and nongovernment 
organizations;  a  review  of  the  legal  framework,  including  private  sector 
engagement;  cost  and  financing;  financial  capacity  of  central  and  local 
governments to provide elderly care services; incentive structures to promote 
private sector investment and management (both profit and nonprofit); special 
actions for vulnerable groups and women; and human resources development. A 
limited number of field visits will be organized within  the PRC to learn from 
successful experiences. 
(ii)  Output  2:  Capacity  development  on  elderly  care  services  planning.  A 
training needs assessment will constitute the basis for the preparation of training 
materials and delivery of training for concerned officials of YMG, the private 
sector,  and  civil  society  stakeholders.  Anticipated  training  topics  will  include 
elderly  needs  assessment,  services  planning  and  costing,  human  resources 
development, and quality monitoring. The TA will also organize an overseas 
study tour12 on elderly care systems planning, development, and monitoring for 
key officials. 
(iii)  Output 3: Elderly service facilities construction plan of Yichang reviewed 
and a strategic elderly care services development plan prepared. The TA 
will assess the elderly service facilities construction plan of Yichang. Primary 
data will be collected through a survey (disaggregated by sex and other relevant 
aspects) to better understand the care needs of the elderly, and the extent to 
which  these  are  currently  covered.  Participatory  reviews,  focus  group 
discussions,  and  planning  workshops  that  include  beneficiaries,  public  and 
private  sector  professionals,  and  decision  makers  will  help  develop  and 
determine the broad strategies, structure (including institutional arrangements), 
and timeline of a realistic strategic plan.  
                                                
12 The study tour will take place in Asia in at least two countries (e.g., Japan and the Republic of Korea) with a focus 
on establishing public-private partnerships for nursing homes, community, and home-based care.

4   
(iv)  Output 4: Dissemination of findings. Two workshops and a final conference 
will be held to disseminate TA findings, with participation by local, provincial, 
national, and international experts. A policy brief knowledge product on elderly 
care system development for the PRC decision makers will be prepared. A final 
TA report will be submitted to YMG and ADB. 
 
11.  Potential risks are (i) inadequate or delayed provision of necessary data, (ii) delayed 
submission of required studies, (iii) inadequate performance of consultants, and (iv) inefficient 
dissemination of TA findings and outputs. To mitigate risks, the recruitment and performance of 
consultants will be monitored closely. The government has agreed to provide all necessary data 
in  a  timely  manner  and  adequate  counterpart  support.  Close  coordination  among  the 
consultants,  YMG,  and  ADB  will  further  mitigate  risks,  as  will  the  establishment  of  a 
multisectoral steering committee. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $450,000, of which $350,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of the provision of office accommodation and venues for 
selected meetings, counterpart staff (YMG staff) and allowances, miscellaneous administration 
expenses,  local transportation for field  visits  within  Yichang  Municipality,  and  other  in-kind 
contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  YMG will be the executing agency for the TA. The Yichang Finance Bureau (YFB) will be 
the implementing agency. YMG and YFB will each designate a senior staff member as TA focal 
points. A project steering committee composed of concerned Yichang government bureaus and 
agencies, relevant educational institutions, private sector representatives, and representatives 
of beneficiaries will be established. YMG will chair the project steering committee and convene 
quarterly meetings. 
 
14.  The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in accordance with ADB's TA Disbursement 
Handbook  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  To  facilitate  implementation,  ADB  may 
establish an advance payment facility for YFB to support certain agreed cash expenditures— 
including workshop, survey, training and overseas study tour, and administrative costs—with 
details of the proposed activities, including cost estimates, submitted through the executing 
agency to ADB for approval. ADB may also make certain direct payments (e.g., for workshop 
venues). 
 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 12 months, tentatively from 18 July 2014 to 23 July 
2015. In dialogue with YMG and YFB, ADB will engage two national (12 person-months) and an 
international consultant (3 person-months), who will report to YFB and ADB, and as requested, 
to YMG. The TA will also recruit a national consultant (3 person-months) on a lump-sum basis 
to implement a survey on the needs of and services for elderly people. The consultants will be 
hired on an individual basis in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2013, as amended from time to time). The two national consultants will include specialists with 
expertise in (i) elderly care including social and community care approaches, health, training, 
and survey methodology; and (ii) elderly care and private sector development, including not-for-
profit approaches, finance, and planning. The senior international consultant will be an aging 
specialist with multi-country expertise in elderly care services planning. Consultant reports will

5 
be prepared in Chinese and English. The outline terms of reference for consultants are in 
Appendix 3. 
 
16.  Regular meetings and seminars will be held involving concerned Yichang government 
bureaus and agencies, relevant educational institutions, and private sector representatives. TA 
achievements  will  be  disseminated  through  two  workshops  during  the  preparation  of  the 
Yichang  elderly  care services  strategic  development  plan, the  preparation  of  a knowledge 
product on elderly care systems development in the PRC, and a final conference on TA findings 
with local, provincial, national, and international experts.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $350,000 on a grant basis to 
the People’s Republic of China for Strategic Elderly Care Services Development in Yichang, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will recruit  an international and three national 
consultants. The consultants will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). 
 
2.  Senior aging and elderly care services specialist (international, 3 person-months). 
The specialist should have a postgraduate degree in economics or social sciences with at least 
10  years  of  multicountry  experience  in  elderly  care  planning.  Experience  in  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) and good command of the Chinese language are major advantages. 
The specialist will report to the team leader and perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Advise the executing agency (Yichang Municipal Government [YMG]) and the 
implementing agency (Yichang Finance Bureau [YFB]) regarding elderly care 
services planning for Yichang Municipality. 
(ii)  Prepare the study report on the national and international experience with elderly 
care  services,  taking  into  account  specific  topics  recommended  by  Yichang 
officials. 
(iii)  Review and comment on the Yichang elderly service facilities construction plan 
and advise on priority areas for the preparation of the Yichang elderly services 
strategic development plan. 
(iv)  Review and provide comments on the study protocol to assess the care needs of 
the elderly and the current gaps in care provision through primary data collection 
on senior citizens, including the survey instrument. Ensure that survey tool and 
analysis address gender and vulnerability. 
(v)  Support  the  two  national  consultants  in  developing  the  training  material  for 
concerned YMG officials.  
(vi)  Advise regarding the identification of study countries for the overseas trip, and 
facilitate contacts. 
(vii)  Assist the team leader in preparing the Yichang elderly care services strategic 
development  plan  and  provide  regular  feedback  on  the  progress  made  in 
developing the plan. 
(viii)  Prepare a policy brief knowledge product in coordination with the two national 
consultants; the outline and content of the knowledge product will be agreed with 
YMG, YFB, and ADB. 
 
3.  Senior social scientist and aging specialist and team leader (national, 7 person-
months). The specialist should have a postgraduate degree in social sciences or a related field, 
with at least 10 years of general experience, and 5 years of experience in elderly care systems 
development and household surveys. ADB and YFB could select the national private sector 
development expert as the team leader depending on her or his demonstrated skills; this would 
lead to a reallocation of person-months of consultancy services. The consultant should be fluent 
in English. The specialist will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Contribute to the development of the study report under the responsibility of the 
international consultant by providing inputs on national best practices in elderly 
care. 
(ii)  Carry out a limited number of field visits to collect detailed information on national 
best practices in agreement with YMG and YFB. 
(iii)  Finalize  the  training  materials  in  coordination  with  the  other  national  and 
international consultants. 
(iv)  Take into account the findings of the assessment of the care needs of the elderly 
and the current gaps in care provision.

other consultants; the plan will be submitted at regular intervals to YFB and YMG 
for feedback and guidance.  
(xi)  Prepare the required reports, including the final technical assistance (TA) report, 
which will include all outputs prepared by the consultants recruited under the TA. 
 
4.  Senior  private  sector  development  specialist  (national,  5  person-months).  The 
specialist should have a postgraduate degree in business administration or a related field with at 
least 10 years of experience in planning techniques and financing, and 2 years of experience in 
elderly care systems development. She or he should be fluent in English. The specialist will 
report to the team leader and perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Contribute to the development of the study report under the responsibility of the 
international consultant by providing inputs on national best practices in elderly 
care. 
(ii)  Carry out a limited number of field visits to collect detailed information on national 
best practices in agreement with YMG and/or YFB. 
(iii)  Train  concerned  Yichang  municipal  officials  in  coordination  with  the  other 
national  consultants,  including  on  elderly  care  costing  and  public–private 
partnership approaches. 
(iv)  Contribute to the development of training materials in coordination with the other 
national and international consultants. 
(v)  Assist in assessing the Yichang elderly care service facilities construction plan. 
(vi)  Participate as a resource person in two participatory workshops and the final 
conference.  
(vii)  Assist the team leader in preparing the Yichang elderly care services strategic 
development  plan  and  provide  regular  feedback  on  the  progress  made  in 
developing the plan. 
(viii)  Provide inputs relevant to the preparation of the required reports, including the 
final TA report. 
 
5.  Senior survey expert in social sectors (national, 3 person-months). The expert should 
have  a  postgraduate  degree  in  social sciences  or  a related field  with  at  least  8  years  of 
experience in planning and implementing surveys in social sectors. Experience in the area of 
elderly care will be a major plus. She or he should be fluent in English. The expert will be 
recruited individually on a lump-sum basis and will report to the team leader and cooperate with 
the international consultant.  
 
6.  The objective of the assignment is to plan and carry out a study through primary data 
collection to assess the care needs of the urban elderly in Yichang Municipality and the current 
gaps in care provision. She or he will perform the following tasks:

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
(i)  Develop a study protocol, including the selection of an appropriate sampling 
framework and an existing survey instrument, given the objectives of the study 
and the available resources. 
(ii)  Agree on the study protocol, the survey instrument and analytical approach with 
the team leader, YFB, and ADB. 
(iii)  Recruit and train data collectors. 
(iv)  Arrange and supervise data collection, data encoding, and analysis. 
(v)  Implement quality assurance measures for every stage of the study. 
(vi)  Prepare a report on survey findings  (including analysis of gender and other 
relevant issues) and include recommendations useful for TA implementation. 
(vii)  Present survey findings to YFB and ADB.
